entry.title: Brother, can you spare the air?
entry.summary:
As firefighters finally are able to contain the still 9 ongoing wildfires that have ravaged the Lake in Calaveras counties this month, I find myself reflecting on the men and women working to bring equanimity to the foothills of the Sierras. I

At times this summer more than 10,000 people collectively worked to up and down the state from Southern Califormia all the way up to Trinity National Forest. Cal Fire and civilian volunteers make up the majoirti, but approximately one-third are inmates from low to medium security prisons. Considering how overcrowded prisons are in the state, it is a resourceful way to allow these prisoners the ability to gain a unique, rehabilitative experience outside the suffocating walls of the prison yard. In

Regardless of the firefighter’s personal journey to the incinerated lands consuming our drought-stricken landscape, they all ore unified by the threats of falling trees and the historical circumstances they fund themselves in. when working on these long he, I’m reminded of Philip Levine’s poem, “Fire,” where he describes the physical and mental ramifactions of battling these blazes. It’s hard and exhausting work on these

A fire burns along the eastern rim
of mountains. In the valley we
see it as a celestial prank, for
in the summer haze the mountains
themselves are lost, but as the night
deepens the fire grows more golden
and dense. On this calm ground
the raw raging of burning winds
that cuts the eyes and singes the hair
is seen as a pencil-line of light
moving southward. I know my son
is there, has been for four days,
moved in and out by helicopters
with his squad of fire fighters.
By now, without sleep, they’ve
gone beyond exhaustion. Some can’t
waken, some are crazed, a few
go on— the oldest— working steadily.
I know this from the stories he
has told me of other famous fires
from which he returned as from
a dream, his eyes glazed with seeing,
his time and place gone.
He would raise his shaking right arm
above his head, and with his palm
open sweep it toward me again
and again and speak without grammar,
sometimes without words, of what
had taken place. I knew it was true.
Now in the cool of the evening I catch
a hint of the forest, of that taking
of sudden breath that pines demand;
it’s on my skin, a light oil, a sweat
born of some forgotten leaning into fire.

In these expansive terrains that make up the Western United States, forest fires may be a distant thought. “In the valley we see it as a celestial prank, for in the summer haze the mountains themselves are lost,” shows the disconnect someone may have from these fires while in the city or valley. The hazy sun distorts the conception of climate change, but then you “catch a hint of the forst” while looking out at the smoke-stained clounds on the Eastern horizon, and it spurs the realization of the country’s

remove file
